comment.author: 92784762@N00
comment._content:
Interesting work. I like the project...
The boundary between art and advertising can be indistinct.

The biggest and most influential contemporary art collector in Britain is Charles Saatchi, who is is one of the brothers who runs Saatchi & Saatchi which is one of the biggest advertising companies in the country.

I expect Warhol would have thought that internet advertising was art...
Afterall he thought traditional advertising was art.

I hope this comment isn't seen as undermining the project.
That is not the intention, rather just opening up the debate.

I hope the discussion event went well.

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: HI Topsy, not at all - a lot of this came up in the panel last night and it was really interesting to hear everyone talk about it.  It seems like this project has really struck a chord and gets people talking on a bunch of different issues.   For us, it was interesting to see these objects in a new way - I'm pretty familiar with these works and to see pieces of them at random where I least expect it is what surprises me and sort of gets me looking at these objects again.  Steve is working to find curators - he's aiming for a different show every two weeks, so I'm curious to see what comes next - you guys should curate a show in add-art :)  -s

comment.author: 92784762@N00
comment._content:
Hi Shelley, to tell you the truth, I am still in awe with the internet. It is such an amazing place that the few bits of advertising that I notice don't bother me. I do hate flashing adverts but I don't seem to come across them that often. In England I think you would be surprised how slow most people are to cotton onto the net. The vast majority of the artists in the studios at Waygood do not have broadband at home. Most of them do not really see the potential of the net!!! People use email but do not yet understand the real significance of what this technology has to offer. 

How would we work with Steve to curate a show in add-art?
